title: How to Learn Fly Fishing

steps.headline: Ask a friend to instruct you on basic fly fishing techniques.
steps.description: You may feel more comfortable trying the new activity with someone familiar to you. However, someone who is not a regular instructor may not be able to supply you with all the tips a beginning fly fisherman needs.

steps.headline: Post a Craigslist ad for a fly fishing partner and instructor.
steps.description: Post in the "Community" section of the site, or look for an existing fly fishing group in the current listings.

steps.headline: Request a fly fishing pamphlet from your state's Department of Natural Resources.
steps.description: Many states publish detailed information on the necessary equipment and skills for a local fly fisherman. You may also learn tips about what flies are most successful throughout the fishing season.

steps.headline: Visit your local library.
steps.description: If you are autodidactic, then searching for instructional books, audiobooks or videos may provide you with enough information to get started. If your library does not currently have books on fly fishing, you may request them.

steps.headline: Call your local Orvis store, or other fishing supply store, to inquire about free classes in the store.
steps.description: Orvis offers free "Fly Fishing 101" courses each spring or summer to teach people how to get started. They have also recently started offering "Fly Fishing 201" courses to help beginners move on to the next level. Although personal instruction is likely to reap the most benefits, if you are not near an Orvis store, you can contact your local fly shop or access fly fishing videos online. Visit howtoflyfish.orvis.com/video-lessons for step by step instructional videos.

steps.headline: Go to YouTube and look for videos on fly fishing instruction.
steps.description: A number of outfitters provide free lessons online as an example of their talents. You can find tips and tricks from a number of avid fly fishermen. EXPERT TIP																															Kathy Sparrow, MA																Fishing Instructor								Kathy Sparrow is a fly-fishing instructor and adventurer at heart. Kathy is the co-founder and previous manager of the Kingfisher Inn, a fly-fishing lodge on the Lower Laguna Madre in Texas. She is the author of "On the Mother Lagoon: Flyfishing and the Spiritual Journey" and "The Whispered Teachings of Grandmother Trout” a novel conveying the feminine perspective of fly fishing. Kathy is also a Certified Canfield Trainer in Canfield Methodologies. She guides individuals through the process of embracing change by expressing confidence, awareness, and courage through the tools of writing, fly fishing, and intentional conversation. She has a MA in English with an emphasis in Literature and Cultural Studies from the University of Texas-Pan American. Kathy Sparrow, MA			Fishing Instructor				Our Expert Agrees: YouTube is a great resource if you're trying to learn to fly fish, because there are so many experts who have their videos online. It can also be helpful to get a magazine subscription, like a saltwater or freshwater publication.

steps.headline: Become part of a fishing club.
steps.description: In some areas of the UK, you are required to pay dues to a fishing club in order to fish in the local streams. These clubs provide access to excellent tips and fishing partners for a fee that is likely to be less than 100 pounds.

steps.headline: Hire a fly fishing guide.
steps.description: Postings and contacts are available through most fly fishing stores. You can arrange to be guided by the hour or by the day, depending upon your flexibility.

steps.headline: Go on a guided fly fishing trip.
steps.description: Many states with rivers have numerous fly fishing outfitters that will include gear, rafts, flotation devices and more with a 1 to 7-day package. If you start fishing on a trip dedicated to fly fishing, you are likely to get enough practice in 1 trip to start fly fishing on your own.

steps.headline: Search for resources online, or find local fly fishing schools.
steps.description: There is an abundant amount of knowledge online for the beginner fly angler. Or, if you choose to find and contact a local fly fishing school—these entities hire experts who are experienced fly fishers and trained in teaching. You can learn the sport by going to regular outdoor classes, which will steadily increase your knowledge.

steps.headline: Visit local fly fishing shops to inquire about instructional resources.
steps.description: Some shops can provide discounts on outfitters and more if you buy your materials in house. You will also be able to obtain a fly fishing license from most shops.

steps.headline: Get a subscription to fly fishing magazines, such as Catch, Fly Fisherman or Fly, Rod & Reel.
steps.description: Although this will not provide the first basic steps, it can be a good way for a beginning angler to learn the lingo and techniques associated with the sport.

steps.headline: Learn the basic casting strategies via youtube or a book and go out fishing.
steps.description: The number one way to learn how to fly fish is to spend time doing it. Nobody can tell you all of the small details involved in catching fish and perfecting your cast. There is no substitute for spending time on the water. Learning the perfect muscle memory for judging distance and fly presentation cannot be taught by a guide or a book, It simply takes time.

steps.headline: Buy a low weight fishing rod to begin with.
steps.description: While you are learning, buy a 6 weight rod that will suffice to catch trout, bass and other small fish. You can buy a heavier rod if you take to the sport and go fishing for larger game.

steps.headline: Practice at a local lake or stream before going on a trip.
steps.description: Learning to practice nearby has the advantage of comfort and accessibility. Many people make the mistake of booking an expensive trip and then they get frustrated when they spend the majority of the trip learning the basics.

steps.headline: Do your fly research.
steps.description: Successful fly fishermen learn to "match the hatch." Study a chart of what insects are hatching in your area at a certain time, and buy according to the schedule.

steps.headline: Buy a graphite fishing rod with a complimentary line.
steps.description: These relatively new rods are easier to wield. The majority of your action should be confined to your dominant arm and shoulder.

steps.headline: Hold the fishing rod like you are shaking a hand.
steps.description: Hold it in the center of the grip with your thumb up. Place your line between your first finger and the fly rod. Pull 8 to 10 yards (7.3 to 9.1 m) of extra line. Cast your line horizontally using your thumb and wrist to flick toward your target.

steps.headline: Relax as you cast.
steps.description: Stiff muscles will lead to short, ineffective casting. Master forward casting in a relaxed way before attempting back casting.

steps.headline: Practice taking apart your reel and putting it back together.
steps.description: Reeling in a catch in fly fishing is very similar to spinning, but putting together a reel will help you to understand different line weights. Once you are very familiar with your reels you will be better at reeling in slowly, smoothly and successfully.

Basic Fly Fishing Tips Buy a low weight fishing rod to begin with. While you are learning, buy a 6 weight rod that will suffice to catch trout, bass and other small fish. You can buy a heavier rod if you take to the sport and go fishing for larger game. Practice at a local lake or stream before going on a trip. Learning to practice nearby has the advantage of comfort and accessibility. Many people make the mistake of booking an expensive trip and then they get frustrated when they spend the majority of the trip learning the basics. Do your fly research. Successful fly fishermen learn to "match the hatch." Study a chart of what insects are hatching in your area at a certain time, and buy according to the schedule. Buy a graphite fishing rod with a complimentary line. These relatively new rods are easier to wield. The majority of your action should be confined to your dominant arm and shoulder. Hold the fishing rod like you are shaking a hand. Hold it in the center of the grip with your thumb up. Place your line between your first finger and the fly rod. Pull 8 to 10 yards (7.3 to 9.1 m) of extra line. Cast your line horizontally using your thumb and wrist to flick toward your target. Relax as you cast. Stiff muscles will lead to short, ineffective casting. Master forward casting in a relaxed way before attempting back casting. Practice taking apart your reel and putting it back together. Reeling in a catch in fly fishing is very similar to spinning, but putting together a reel will help you to understand different line weights. Once you are very familiar with your reels you will be better at reeling in slowly, smoothly and successfully.
